repnme.cdata!: India - Second Madras Water Supply Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey a satisfactory project
            outcome, likely sustainability, and substantial
            institutional development impacts, supported by satisfactory
            performances by the Bank and Borrower. Lessons address the
            following. Concerning water supply and sewerage services,
            risk analysis should precede project implementation, focused
            more on the risks that sufficient raw water might not be
            available. In turn, an appropriate analysis of these supply
            risks must put greater emphasis on the broader issues of
            water resources management, and on identifying the
            least-cost sequence of developing different supply schemes,
            including consideration to a low-cost supply for providing
            base load, and a higher-cost supply which can be mobilized
            when "Peak Demand" needs to be met. Second, an
            analysis should be done to track the effective capacity of
            each component in the supply/distribution chain, in order to
            identify any bottlenecks, and then remove them. As a result
            of the failure to undertake such an analysis, Chennai seems
            to have over-invested in treatment capacity, and
            underinvested in the distribution system and in metering.
            Third, the reliance on private sub-contractors, demands much
            of Metrowater's ability to supervise not only the cost
            of outsourced services, but also the quality provided by the
            sub-contractors. It would thus be prudent to invest more in
            training Metrowater staff in monitoring, and controlling its
            private sub-contractors, particularly with respect to the
            proper maintenance of the outsourced facilities. In
            particular, Metrowater would be well advised to prepare for
            the introduction of metering for domestic consumers.

repnme.cdata!: India - Second Madras Water Supply Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Madras has the lowest level of water
            supply of all metropolitan areas in India and great
            susceptibility to drought. The project's major
            objectives are to: 1) provide water from a reliable source
            within the State to Madras on an urgent basis; 2) improve
            the distribution of water within Madras; and 3) strengthen
            conservation. The project will consist of the following: 1)
            source works at the existing Veeranam irrigation tank to the
            south of Madras; 2) a transmission pipeline from Veeranam to
            Madras, a distance of 235 km, with associated treatment and
            pumping facilities; 3) continuation of distribution
            improvements within Madras being undertaken in the First
            Madras Supply Project; 4) a water conservation program
            including physical works such as leak detection and repairs
            and tariff increases to encourage more efficient use of
            water; and 5) technical assistance in the form of project
            preparation and implementation support. Adequate steps will
            be taken to ensure people adversely affected benefit from
            the project where this is possible and otherwise are made no
            worse off as a result. To remove possible farmer resistance
            to the proposals at Veeranam, a new regime to regulate the
            flow has been introduced following consultation under which
            the irrigation flows will exceed those that would otherwise
            have occurred.

repnme.cdata!:
India - Second Madras Water Supply Project
            : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The study area encompasses the area
            within the Madras Metropolitan Authority (MMA) boundary;
            areas presently irrigated from the Veeranam lake, and the
            area surrounding Veeranam lake; the routes of the water
            supply canals which transport water to the Veeranam lake;
            the routes of the water supply from Veeranam lake to the
            proposed distribution storage reservoir sites in the city;
            the site of the existing water treatment facility at
            Vadakuthu and proposed water treatment plant site, pumping
            stations/booster station; and the sites of proposed
            distribution reservoirs, or the site of any other component
            of the project identified by the feasibility study.  The
            study provides: 1) information on policy, legal and
            administrative framework for environmental assessment at
            state, national and international level; 2) an assessment of
            the baseline environmental status with respect to the
            physical, biological and socio-cultural environment of the
            project area; and 3) an overview of the predicted impacts of
            the project activities on air, noise, ecology, water, land
            and socio-economic components of the environment.
